awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Public Funding of Sanitation Infrastructure:  An analysis of Voter Behavior and Health Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
Clean water and sewers are essential for economic development. But how the provision of such sanitation infrastructure is affected by political institutions remains unknown, even though classic theoretical results predict more spending on clean water and sewers as governments become democratic.  However, these theoretical papers, as well as most empirical studies, focus on government redistribution.  They ignore the very real possibility that demand for sanitary infrastructure is increasing in income, and if it is, then democracy could be associated with less spending on clean water and sewers, particularly when the poor get the right to vote.  Using an original data set, the proposed research seeks to resolve this issue by studying how government investment in sanitation infrastructure is shaped by the extension of voting rights to the poor and its consequences for health and mortality rates.

The data set comes from Britain in the years 1870-1914.  Nineteenth-century Britain offers a valuable opportunity for testing how political institutions influenced government spending on sanitation infrastructure.  The rapid urbanization accompanying the Industrial Revolution overwhelmed existing sanitary infrastructure, and left local governments facing new demands for public goods that they were ill-equipped to handle.  The study exploits variation in the size of the electorate over time and across towns to test the effects of extending the franchise on the level of sanitary investment and mortality.  This project constructs a new comprehensive annual dataset of mortality, sanitary investment and the extent of the franchise at town-level.  In addition to testing the effect of political institutions on infrastructure spending, the dataset will also be used to identify the importance of sanitary investment for the decline in mortality rates during the period, which will shed light on the ability of subnational governments to counter the health consequences of urbanization.  Further, the study will complement recent work by economic historians in measuring and explaining growth in government capacity at the local level and hence, importantly, investments in sanitation infrastructure.  At the conclusion of the project efforts will be made to make the data publicly available through the Global Price and Incomes History group or the IPCSR.

por.por_cntn:
Project outcomes report

Jonathan Chapman has completed research for his dissertation “Death or taxes? The political economy of sanitation expenditure in nineteenth-century Britain” supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement  Grant. The dissertation explores the political obstacles to government investment in important local public goods—in particular, sanitation infrastructure—through a study of nineteenth-century England. The results of the dissertation show that both the poor and the rich opposed expenditure on local public goods, and that extensions of voting rights to the poor led to a reduction in government expenditure and, as a result, likely slowed improvements in public health.

The dissertation argues, using a mathematical model, that the poor and the rich desire lower public goods expenditure than the middle class: the rich because of the relatively high tax burden, and the poor because of their high marginal utility of consumption. (In other words, rather than paying taxes for sanitation infrastructure, they preferred consuming other goods and services, such as better food or housing.) This hypothesis is tested using a new dataset from England between 1867 and 1900, collected with the support of the NSF. This dataset includes information on the extent of voting rights—the proportion of the population that had the right to vote—and spending by town councils on local public goods. The results show that the level of expenditure was highest when approximately 50% of the adult male population held the right to vote.

These findings indicate that political participation of the very poor can lead to lower expenditure on local public goods that are critical to economic development. Historical and contemporary evidence from other countries has shown that government investment in both water supply and sewer systems can greatly reduce mortality, suggesting that extensions of the franchise in England may have had a negative impact on public health. But that is not necessarily the case, because it is possible that spending on infrastructure was corrupt or inefficient, particularly at a time when sanitation technology was rudimentary, and the most effective form of government intervention was unclear.

The final part of the dissertation test the effectiveness of sanitation expenditure on mortality by constructing a new dataset linking local mortality to town expenditure. The results show that the expenditure on sanitation cut the death rate from waterborne diseases, including cholera and diarrhea, with particularly strong effects on children aged under 5. These findings suggest that the political opposition to greater government expenditure prevented improvements in public health.
